title: Rename a VMDK disk and all its files with VMware Virtual Disk Manager and Workstation Pro
content:
Rename a VMDK disk and all its files with VMware Virtual Disk Manager and Workstation Pro

We are going to rename this machine. The filename is quite verbose and the machine has many associated files we need to rename. ![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/4037d2da-a462-481d-b401-886600120487.png) The VMware Virtual Disk Manager is a tool that is included with VMware Workstation. It is typically installed into the following folder: ![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/402361e2-ae9b-48af-87fd-262e33d86b42.png) This folder contains lots of files. Check for the presence of the VMware Disk Manager tools by using a wildcard character following some of the initial prefix e.g. `dir vmware*` ![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/8178958e-538e-408e-b1a7-5dfa013861a8.png) Great so the tools is present. We want to rename out VMware contained in the following folder. ![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/6f0260cd-80f9-41df-93ed-0d02ea1422a4.png) As I do not need the VM Image to function from inside VM Workstation I am going to remove the image. Note this does not delete it from the disk. ![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/c4c8d118-be48-4b21-85dd-d427bf44e7bf.png) Next I am going to install a new VM in a directory with the desired name in my desired location. ![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/e24fd357-5b49-45a6-a223-4066f2d46903.png) When asked choose \

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/d4bd3db2-3483-4305-b247-64e8aabb223f.png)

Set this new VM in your desired location and choose the name you wish for your VM

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/a7d0e6bd-5d6f-42d4-913e-f6d5443dea5a.png)

Before finishing I like to customise the machines hardware. For this machine I am going to perform the following

* Remove Printer
* Remove Sound Card
* Increase memory to 8GB
* Go to \

. Then change the Graphics memory to 1GB. 
* Under the CPU I will select the following checkboxes. 
  * Virutalize Intel VT-x/EPT or AMD-V/RVI
  * Virtualize CPU Performance Counters
  * Virtualize IOMMU (IO memory management unit)

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/d51ac3db-c28a-4086-bfcf-2e76d47cc9e4.png)

With our machine installed we can now check the VM folder.

A quick way to get to the folder is to right click on the machine name and select \

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/20597e9e-77d2-4f59-8e88-5c815b86bbbf.png)

With the folder open we can now see our new VM and all of its files. 

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/55b44e9e-97b2-496c-9b07-96bda3b63415.png)

Remove the Hard disk from the VM in workstation. 

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/2e4729c1-57eb-4405-a3e4-6db424a68bcd.png)

Delete the file from the hard drive 

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/ad84b612-aa33-4688-b147-cb3980eb3968.png)

Next we use the Virtual Disk Manager to rename the old hardrive and place it in the new location. 

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/51344998-baca-45f7-9c37-5d695b7dc4d1.png)

> Note: This will  move the hardrive from the original folder. You might want to make a copy. 

Now all is left is to attach the hard drive. 

Got to settings `CTRL` + `D` and click \

. 

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/cfaa8558-28da-44df-a163-6907eb78b930.png)

Select the disk you just created and click \

![](/media/media/markdown/2021/03/20/36abb1ba-0e9f-4c07-8a37-0ca82a01313e.png)

You can now delete the old folder that contained your machine Hard Disk and boot your new machine up.
